fields.name: Ada Lovelace
fields.bio: The first computer programmer. She wrote the first algorithm intended for a machine — Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine.

fields.name: Grace Hopper
fields.bio: A U.S. Navy rear admiral and computer scientist who developed the first compiler and helped create COBOL.

fields.name: Margaret Hamilton
fields.bio: Led the team that developed software for NASA's Apollo 11 mission. Coined the term 'software engineering'.

fields.name: Katherine Johnson
fields.bio: A NASA mathematician whose calculations of orbital mechanics were critical to the success of U.S. spaceflights.

fields.name: Radia Perlman
fields.bio: Known as the 'Mother of the Internet' for her invention of the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP), essential for network bridges.

fields.name: Hedy Lamarr
fields.bio: Hollywood actress and inventor who co-created a frequency-hopping system — the foundation for Wi-Fi and Bluetooth.

fields.name: Annie Easley
fields.bio: A NASA computer scientist and rocket scientist who developed software for the Centaur rocket stage.

fields.name: Carol Shaw
fields.bio: One of the first female video game designers and programmers. Known for the game River Raid (1982).

fields.name: Shafi Goldwasser
fields.bio: A cryptographer who won the Turing Award for her work in complexity theory and cryptographic protocols.

fields.name: Tracy Chou
fields.bio: Software engineer and diversity advocate. Launched the #WhereAreTheTechWomen movement and founded Block Party.

fields.name: Kimberly Bryant
fields.bio: Founder of Black Girls Code, a nonprofit that teaches coding to girls from underrepresented communities.

fields.name: Fei-Fei Li
fields.bio: A leading AI researcher and professor. Known for building ImageNet and pushing ethical AI discussions.
